Mechanism and Machine Theory

A new model analysis approach for bridge-type amplifiers supporting nano-stage design
Pengbo Liua, b, Peng Yana, b, c,∗ aKey Laboratory of High-efficiency and Clean Mechanical Manufacture (Shandong University), Ministry of Education, Jinan, Shandong 250061, China bSchool of Mechanical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, Shandong 250061, China cSchool of Automation Science and Electrical Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing 100191, China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 11 May 2015 Received in revised form 12 December 2015 Accepted 11 January 2016 Available online xxxx
Keywords: Bridge-type amplifier Displacement amplification ratio External load Elastic beam theory Guiding mechanism Finite element analysis (FEA)
A B S T R A C T
This paper presents a new analysis method for bridge-type amplifiers by incorporating the effect of external loads, and establishes a theoretical model to predict the input/output displacement amplification ratio based on elastic beam theory. The new analytical model indicates that the displacement amplification ratio of the bridge-type amplifiers decreases significantly in the presence of external loads, and its changing rate increases with higher external loads. The analysis method is then applied to the modeling and design of a bridgetype-amplifier based nano-manipulating stage, where the guiding mechanism acts as the external load of the bridge-type amplifiers. It is shown that the new analysis method can derive more accurate model of the nano-stage, which is further verified by the finite element analysis (FEA) results. The proposed method offers a new look into the analysis and design of flexure based nano-stages for real applications.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
With the rapid development of advanced manufacturing and measuring techniques, nano manipulating system has become one of the key enabling components in precision instruments [1,2,3]. To satisfy the ultrahigh precision requirement, the smart micro actuators (such as piezoelectric actuators) and various compliant mechanisms have been extensively researched due to their characteristics of high resolution, high bandwidth and fast response [4,5,6,7]. In particular, flexure hinges are key components in compliant mechanisms to generate motions through elastic deformation. Different from traditional revolute joints, the design and analysis of flexure hinges has general challenging issues, such as finite stiffness in the output direction and the drift of the rotational center [8], and has attracted significant research efforts, see e.g. Tian et al. [9,10] and the references therein.
Note that many practical applications such as biological cell manipulation and micro-fluidic chip technology [11,12] usually require a large motion range of more than hundreds micrometers, which is significantly larger than the output displacement of micro actuators. For example, the stroke of a PZT (piezoelectric actuator) is about 0.1% of its own length [13]. Therefore, various displacement amplification mechanisms have been developed supporting nano-manipulating systems, such as lever-type [14,15], bridge-type [13,16], four-bar linkage [17], and Scott-Russell mechanism [18]. In particular, the bridge-type amplifier has attracted significant research and various analytical models have been proposed to predict the amplification ratio, thanks to its compact structure and large displacement amplification ratio.

According to the pseudo-rigid-body model, the flexure hinge can be simplified as an ideal revolute joint associated with a torsional spring and other elements can be taken as rigid bodies. Pokines [19] and Lobontiu [20] derived the ideal displacement amplification ratio of the bridge-type mechanism based on geometric relationship analysis respectively. Ma [13] further simplified the ideal model through instantaneous velocity analysis. Furthermore, considering the effect of translational deformations of the flexure hinges, Ma [13] derived a theoretic displacement amplification ratio using elastic beam theory. Qi [21] further analyzed the input and output displacements through both geometric relations and elastic beam theory and proposed a novel theoretical displacement amplification ratio formula accordingly. Moreover, by assuming flexure hinges as 6 degreeof-freedoms (DOFs) spring elements, Kim [22] proposed the matrix method to model a spatial two-step bridge-type amplifier. With the consideration of both the flexure hinges’ and connecting arms’ deformations, Xu [16] established the analytical model of a flexure-based compound bridge-type (CBT) displacement amplifier. However, most existing models only focused on the characteristics of the individual amplifier. In fact, we have observed that the actual amplification ratio of the bridge-type amplifier in nano-manipulating systems is different from that of the individual amplifiers because of the significant impact of external loads, which inevitably exist in nano-stage systems.
In this paper, we take the effect of external loads into account and propose a novel theoretical model for bridge-type amplifiers. Through this new method, a more accurate displacement amplification ratio can be achieved for real applications. Then the proposed model is applied to the modeling of a bridge-type-amplifier based nano-manipulating stage, where the guiding mechanism acts as the external load of the bridge-type amplifiers. Comparisons between the analytical results and FEA results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed analysis method.
In the rest of the paper, the mechanism description of the bridge-type-amplifier based nano-stage is described in Section 2. Analytical static modeling of the bridge-type amplifier is derived in Section 3, where the effect of external loads on the performance is analyzed. In Section 4, the characteristics of the guiding mechanism is analyzed and the static model of the nano-stage is established. Section 5 verifies the established models by FEA method. Finally, some concluding remarks are summarized in Section 6.

sections.heading: 2. Mechanism description
sections.text:
The schematic diagram of the designed piezo driven nano-stage with a bridge-type amplifier is depicted in Fig. 1. In the proposed nano-stage, the central motion platform is connected to the fixed frame through four leaf springs, which constitutes the guiding mechanism. Due to the leaf springs’ characteristics of high longitudinal stiffness, low transverse stiffness and low stress concentration, the guiding mechanism can well improve the nano-stage’s rejection capability against parasitic motions and other external disturbances [23,24]. Therefore, the proposed nano-stage can move only in the desired direction due to the structural symmetry.
The piezo stack is adopted as the actuator for the nano-stage, thanks to its characteristics of high resolution, high force, high stiffness and fast response. It is located inside the bridge type displacement amplification mechanism, as shown in Fig. 2. The output end of the amplifier is connected to central motion platform. Therefore, the output of the piezo stack is amplified by the bridge-type mechanism and then transferred to the central motion platform accurately. Moreover, the corner-filleted flexure hinges are used in this displacement amplifier because they are more flexible than other types of flexure hinges of the same size. Obviously, in this particular design, the guiding mechanism acts as the external load of the bridge-type amplification mechanism.
As depicted in Fig. 1, the design also incorporates a preload mechanism consisting of four bolts and two compressed springs. With the requirements of assembly, adjustment and looseness-proof of the piezoelectric actuator, two bolts with fine threads are mounted behind the piezoelectric actuator to provide a certain preload. For the purpose of adjusting the preload of the piezoelectric actuator, two compressed springs are symmetrically mounted at the left and the right sides of the bridge-type amplifier by two bolts. The preload is thus applied by tightening the screws, which press the amplifier against the piezoelectric actuator and align the piezoelectric stack with the desired force. In addition, the compressed springs also improve the stiffness of the nano-stage with this arrangement. It is also noted from Fig. 1 that a linear encoder (by MicroE Systems) with a resolution of 1.2 nm is used as the displacement sensor to generate real time position signals on the motion direction.

sections.heading: 3. Analytical modeling of bridge-type amplifier
sections.text: In this section, we first recall several analytical models of the bridge-type amplification mechanism. These models can well predict the amplification ratio of the individual bridge-type amplifiers. However, in most nano-manipulating systems, the bridge-type amplifiers are usually connected to specific driving devices. The simulations and experimental results show that the amplification ratio of the bridge-type amplifiers in nano-manipulating systems is significantly different from the individual amplifiers due to the effect of external loads on amplifiers’ performance. Therefore, a new analysis method for bridge-type amplifiers is developed in this section by incorporating the effect of external loads.

sections.heading: 3.2. Actual modeling of bridge-type amplifier

In this subsection, we investigate the deformations of the flexure hinges induced by external loads and revisit the modeling process. Note that in real applications, the operating range of the bridge-type amplifiers is restricted by the workspace limitation of the overall nano-stage, such that the flexure hinges are usually working in the small deflection range. Therefore we make the following assumptions in the modeling process:
a. The elastic deformations only occur at the flexure hinges, and the links are rigid free of elastic deformations. b. The translational and rotational deformations are small enough to be linearized.
Due to the symmetrical structure of the bride-type amplification mechanism, only one bridge arm is needed to establish the mathematical model, as shown in Fig. 4. sections.heading: 4. Analytical modeling of nano-stage
sections.text: As described in Section 2, the designed nano-stage can be divided into two parts: the bridge-type amplifier and the guiding mechanism. The reactive forces generated by the elastic deformations of guiding mechanism are the external loads imposed on the bridge-type amplifier.

sections.heading: 4.1. Analytical modeling of the guiding mechanism
sections.text:
As depicted in Fig. 7, the four leaf springs form the double four-bar parallelogram mechanism. The symmetric structure through the double connecting bars avoids the parasitic movement in vertical direction. The leaf springs improve the motion capability of the nano-stage. Due to the symmetrical structure and identical working conditions, only one leaf spring is analyzed to establish the mathematical model. The mechanics analysis of one leaf spring is shown in Fig. 8, where we define the generalized force applied at the endpoint Q as Fq = [Fnq, Fsq, Mq]T and the generalized displacement as dQ = [uq,yq, hq]T.
According to the bending deformation theory [25], we can achieve the approximate differential equation of the deflection curve for the leaf spring PQ as
EIy′′(x) = M(x) = Fsq(ls − x) + Mq, (23)

At the fixed end P, the rotation and deflection are zero (i.e., hp = 0, yp = 0). Due to the symmetric structure, the central motion platform has no coupled motion during the movement along y axis. sections.heading: 5. Model verification with FEA
sections.text: In this section, the established analytical models are verified by static analyses carried out with the FEA software ANSYS. The critical parameters of the bridge-type amplifier and the guiding mechanism are listed in Table 1. Besides, the aluminum alloy AL7075-T6 is selected as the material of the nano-stage. The physical and mechanical parameters of this material are also described in Table 1.

sections.heading: 5.1. Simulation on the amplifier
sections.text:
According to the structure illustrated in Fig. 2 and parameters listed in Table 1, the model of the bridge-type amplifier is established. Surface DD1 is fixed and a driving force of 200 N is imposed on the input surfaces AA1 and CC1. The deformation of the amplifier is depicted in Fig. 9. The FEA results indicate that an input displacement of 115.09 lm and an output displacement of 927.53 lm is obtained. Therefore, the displacement amplification ratio of the proposed bridge-type mechanism is 8.06, which coincides with the theoretical value calculated by Eqs. (21), (4) and (5), as declared in Table 2.
Besides, according to Eq. (22), we calculated the critical value of external load as F0 ≈ 0.162Fin. In order to verify the impact of external load, different loads less than F0 are imposed on the output link BB1 with the same driving force of 200 N. Table 2 shows the comparisons between the simulation results obtained by ANSYS and the theoretical results. It is straightforward that the proposed analytical model (21) can well predict the amplification capability of the amplifier in the case of external load existing, while the previous models (4) and (5) can only predict the amplification ratio without external load. However, the amplification ratio as well as the input and output displacements of the bridge-type mechanism decreases with the increase of the external load. The changing rate of the amplification ratio increases with the increase of the external load, as depicted in Fig. 10. Note that
the amplification ratio obtained by FEA is smaller than the theoretic value. The displacement loss is partially due to the reason that the rigid links are not absolute rigid bodies and thus undergo elastic deformations. In addition, the flexure hinges are not the ideal revolute joints and could generate deformations during the process of displacement output. Therefore the rotational center of the flexure will have certain offset and the drift can affect the amplification factor significantly. The above issues are not considered during the simplification of flexure hinges in the present paper and deserve separate studies in future research.
It can be further inferred that if the external load is less than 11.25% of driving force Fin, the amplification ratio drops less than 5%, as shown in Fig. 10. In this case, the previous theoretical models of this type amplifier can be adopted. However, once the external load exceeds this value, the amplification ratio drops seriously and the previous models are no longer suitable.
Recall that all the results derived in this paper are based on the linear assumption of the stiffness of the flexure hinge. It is interesting to further examine the correctness of this assumption when the deformation range of the flexure hinge increases. To this end, different driving forces from 10 N to 2000 N are applied on the input surfaces AA1 and CC1. The simulated amplification ratios and critical forces are plotted in Fig. 11. As illustrated in Fig. 11(a), the simulated amplification ratio can be treated as a constant despite of a slowly increasing slope, and the deviations from the theoretical values are less than 5% if the driving force is less than 600 N. Meanwhile, the critical forces are proportional to the driving forces and the slope is about 0.16 (as shown in Fig. 11(b)), which agrees with the conclusion (22). The results demonstrate that the established models can well predict the behaviors of the amplifier in a small deformation range of the flexure hinge.
It can be also demonstrated in Fig. 11 that the flexure hinges will produce large deflections and the original linear relationship is more nonlinear, when the driving force increases (e.g. larger than 800 N). The theoretical results obtained in this paper cannot predict the behavior of the bridge-type amplifier in this case because the assumptions made in Subsection 3.2 are no longer valid. It is also interesting to explore the nonlinear large deflection characteristics in future research.

sections.heading: 5.2. Simulation on the nano-stage
sections.text:
In the designed nano-stage, the guiding mechanism acts as the external load of the bridge-type amplifier. Similar to the procedure introduced in the last subsection, the 3D model of the proposed nano-stage is established according to the parameters listed in Table 1. Displacement constraints are applied to the four fixing holes, such that all their DOFs are constrained.
We consider a driving force of 500 N at the input end and investigate the output displacement of the central motion platform, as shown in Fig. 12. The FEA results indicate the input displacement of 22.54 lm at the input end and output displacement of 101.31 lm. Therefore, the developed nano-stage has an amplification ratio of 4.49, which is much lower than the theoretical values of the bride-type amplifier without considering the external load. Table 3 shows the comparisons between nano-stage
and single bridge-type amplifier, which clearly demonstrate that the guiding mechanism impacts the performance of the amplifier significantly. The comparisons also indicate that it is necessary to analyze the impact of the external load on the amplifier. By comparing the FEA results and theoretical results of the nano-stage, the proposed analytical method and established model Eq. (33) can well describe the static performance of the nano-stage.

sections.heading: 6. Conclusions
sections.text: In this paper, we develop a new analysis method for bridge-type amplification mechanism with consideration of external loads. Specifically, each flexure hinge of the amplifier is simplified as a 3-DOFs joint and the other elements are considered as rigid bodies. Based on elastic beam theory and kinematic analysis, the input and output displacements, as well as the amplification ratio of the bridge-type amplifier are derived. Furthermore, the proposed analytical model is applied to the modeling of a bridge-type-amplifier based loadsnano-stage, where the guiding mechanism acts as the external load of the amplifier. The developed analytical models are further verified by FEA. The results indicate that the proposed analysis method is more accurate for the analysis and design of bridge-type amplifiers supporting nano-manipulating systems. The proposed method offers a new look into the analysis and design of flexure based nano-stages for real applications.
